utterances: And how did she perish?
She, it seems, fell into a sort of mud hole along a river and we think choked on mud.
There's a little diversity of opinion among the collaborators at the moment, but I think we'll get these things sorted out in due time.
Dan Fisher, I'd like you to take us back to her discovery a couple of years ago, and tell us about the first time that you saw this little mammoth.
I first saw Lyuba the first of July 2007, approximately a month after she was found.
We went to the town of Stalachard(ph), a sort of provincial capital near where she was found, and brought her out of the freezer and had a first really good look over her exterior.
What was that like?
Well, the main reaction, I suppose, was she's just so wonderfully preserved, an all-but-living animal.
What did she look like?

She looks a little dried, but she looks really very much like a baby elephant but with a distinctive hump on the back of her neck, which we now know is made of something called brown fat, a special tissue that's capable of generating warmth.
It helps an animal to maintain its body temperature under cold stress.
Did she have a little wooly coat?
She had the remains of a little wooly coat.
Much of it had fallen out some time after her death, but she otherwise looks really very similar to the way she would have in her life.

You know, Dan Fisher, I know that you've been a scientist on this field of research for a long, long time, but I feel like I can almost hear the excitement in your voice as you think about this little specimen.
Well, that's true, I suppose.
It's hard not to let it out.
She's really so wonderful.
And when you commit so much of your energies and time to understanding some of these problems, to have a chance for this sort of quantum leap in information, it really is special.
Well, Dan Fisher, thank you so much for telling us Lyuba's story today.
Oh, it's my pleasure.
Thank you.
Imagine for a moment that you lent someone $20 billion and he now says, boy, was that a mistake on my part.
I would have been better off asking for just 10.
Well, stop imagining, because U.S.
taxpayers did help out Bank of America to the tune of $20 billion, and the big bank's CEO has said that he now regrets that.
Saskia Scholtes covers U.S.
financial services for the Financial Times, and she joins us now from New York.
Hi.
Hi.
This came up in an interview with Ken Lewis, the CEO of Bank of America.
Yeah.
He came into see us at the Financial Times this morning.
And we asked him whether he regretted taking the government aid and regretted the deal with Merrill Lynch, and he said he'd wished he'd taken only about half of that amount.
Does that mean he's about to pay back $10 billion very soon to the Treasury?
Well, no. I think the government wants him to wait a little while before he pays back that money to be sure that there aren't any further losses down the pike.

But the reason he did give us for wishing he hadn't taken so much is he said that he had asked the $20 billion in what he described as an abundance of caution because the scale of the losses at Merrill Lynch were getting to a state where they were very worried that the capital hit to Bank of America was going to be huge when the deal closed.
But by taking $20 billion, they made the bank look more like Citigroup, and therefore more of a risk of nationalization.
He doesn't believe that that was fair.
So his motive in seeking the aid was for Bank of America to look stronger, and instead it had the reverse effect.
It made the bank look weaker.
Major General JAMES ""MAD DOG"" MATTIS (U.S.
Marine Corps): It must be pretty bad with Marines and soldiers driving through your capital city.
I can't imagine he has much command and control when you take over his country and you drink his liquor, you know?
Doesn't much matter.

Tom Davis said today that based on the detection window for stanozolol, which is, he said, three to four weeks, the committee was unable to conclude that Palmeiro took the substance either purposely or inadvertently before his testimony.

Now according to the committee, Palmeiro's in the clear for that steroid, which showed up in the test administered in early May, but couldn't there have been other steroids in his system when he testified, steroids that might have cycled out before that test was performed?
Certainly, and Davis did address that as well.
He said the committee pursued other leads of people who'd volunteered evidence that maybe Palmeiro had taken steroids prior to the time of his testimony.
The committee asked for additional evidence and ran down some leads and could not substantiate those leads.
Davis said had they been able to, the committee would have pursued the perjury charge.

And amplifying what Davis said, Palmeiro's lawyers yesterday released a statement saying that Palmeiro took a previously undisclosed drug test in 2003 and 2004, tested negative for steroids on both occasions.
Well, they also issued that statement that sort of tempted to make an explanation as to how steroids might possibly have found themselves into Rafael Palmeiro's body.
Yeah, and this was one of the things that was left hanging.
As Tom Davis said, the scope of this investigation was narrow.
They weren't getting into the how he tested positive or why, and one of the things that was left hanging was Palmeiro's contention that it might have been a contaminated vitamin B12 shot.
He said that he took that and it might have happened.
The committee, though, said that it didn't obtain any evidence supporting that.
There was no evidence that the B12, which is a dietary supplement, has ever been inadvertently contaminated with an anabolic steroid, and this backs up what some anti-doping experts say.
So there is, shall we say, skepticism about Mr. Palmeiro's statement?
There is, yes, still some skepticism.
It's up in the air, although Palmeiro's lawyers, doing their job, say there is evidence that B12 and stanozolol can be mixed.

They cite someone from the Dominican Federation of Sports Medicine who says that, `In over 20 years of work in the field I have across instances in which athletes were administered a mix of both substances with and without the knowledge and/or consent of the athlete.
So that's the situation.
Stay tuned, as usual, with this long-running story.
Tom Goldman, thanks very much.
You're welcome, Neal.
NPR sports reporter Tom Goldman joined us from his home base in Portland, Oregon.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And let's move now to Mexico where thousands of teachers are still on strike, despite threats from government officials to end their protests.
Clashes between police and protesters last month left nine people dead and a hundred injured when police tried to stop teachers from blocking roads and highways.
As NPR's Carrie Kahn reports, one of those protesters died yesterday from a head wound sustained during those violent clashes.
Officials with the Section 22 teachers union say a local professor died Tuesday in the southern state of Oaxaca.
Serious clashes between police and protesters occurred on June 11.
Jose Caballero Julian who died yesterday taught indigenous elementary school students in the state.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: (Speaking Spanish)
(SOUNDBITE OF WHISTLE SOUNDING)
Hundreds of teachers remain on strike in Oaxaca and continue blocking roads, like this one set up outside the state's capital.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: (Speaking Spanish).
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #3: (Speaking Spanish).
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: (Speaking Spanish).
Middle school teacher Jose Angel Diaz Labastida and fellow protesters force a trailer truck to the side of the road.
The teachers have been restricting truck traffic for weeks.
(Speaking Spanish).
We are willing to sit down and negotiate with the government whenever and wherever,"" says Diaz.
Teachers are upset about recent national reforms requiring educators to pass standardized tests.
They say the new laws are more aimed at controlling their union than improving Mexico's education system.
The prolonged strike and road blocks have been most intense in Oaxaca and the southern state of Chiapas, leading to food and gas shortages.
The government recently airlifted tons of basic foodstuffs to affected communities.
Despite having warned the striking teachers to remove the roadblocks, Mexico's interior secretary now says he will meet with them on Monday.
Parent Veronica Ruiz Ramirez (ph) says the unresolved conflict has the state on edge.
(Speaking Spanish).
It's a tense calm here in Oaxaca,"" she says, just days before the school year is drawing to an end.
Carrie Kahn, NPR News, Oaxaca, Mexico.
Well, joining us now is Ann Cun, who's an immigration lawyer in the San Francisco Bay Area who helps tech companies bring over foreign employees on the H-1B visa program.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks for having me.
